description: Borrowed into Middle English from Latin vulgāris, from volgus, vulgus (“mob; common folk”), from Proto-Indo-European *wl̥k- (compare Welsh gwala (“plenty, sufficiency”), Ancient Greek ἁλία (halía, “assembly”) εἰλέω (eiléō, “to compress”), Old Church Slavonic великъ (velikŭ, “great”).

adjectives.description: vulgar (comparative more vulgar or vulgarer, superlative most vulgar or vulgarest)

examples: a truly vulgar showing of affection

entries.meaning: (classical sense) Having to do with ordinary, common people.
examples: The mechanical process of multiplying books had brought the New Testament in the vulgar tongue within the reach of every class.

entries.meaning: (especially taxonomy) Common, usual; of the typical kind.

examples: A fraction is vulgar if it has one integer divided by another integer, as long as the integer that's doing the dividing isn't equal to zero.

Popular antiquarian writings  […]  frequently focused on the regional vulgars' superstitious beliefs regarding the dead and their ongoing presence—such as popular funeral rites or the vulgars' fear of church yards.

entries.meaning: The vernacular tongue or common language of a country.
